\chapter{Latest version: 0.7.241}
\label{\detokenize{index:latest-version-0-7-241}}\label{\detokenize{index:apero-doc-main-latest}}\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
APERO is a pipeline designed to reduce astrophysical observations (specifically from echelle spectrographs).
It is the official pipeline for:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.cfht.hawaii.edu/Instruments/SPIRou/}{SPIROU} (SPectropolarimeter InfraROUge) on the Canada\sphinxhyphen{}France\sphinxhyphen{}Hawaii Telescope \sphinxhref{https://www.cfht.hawaii.edu/}{CFHT}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
APERO can also be used for:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
NIRPS HE (Currently under construction)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
NIRPS HA (Currently under construction)

\end{itemize}
\end{quote}


\section{General User documentation}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/main_general:general-user-documentation}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/main_general:general-guide}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/main_general::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section provides a general guide to using APERO.


\subsection{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:id1}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you have installed APERO you can read about running APERO
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:using-apero-default}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Guide for installing python can be found {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-installation}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{Download from GitHub}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:download-from-github}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-download}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to your desired installation directory (from now on this is referred to
as {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-0}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_ROOT}}}}) e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/home/user/bin/apero\sphinxhyphen{}drs/}}


\paragraph{Clone}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:clone}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone from \sphinxhref{https://github.com/njcuk9999/apero-drs}{github}
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git clone https://github.com/njcuk9999/apero\PYGZhy{}drs
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This may take some time (in future most of the data required will be a separate download),
and we still have many (now redundant) files from the spirou\_py3 repository.


\paragraph{Choose branch}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:choose-branch}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-choose-branch}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to the \sphinxtitleref{\{DRS\_ROOT\}} directory

\sphinxAtStartPar
Choose which branch:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{master version}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the version currently recommended for all general use.
It may not contain the most up\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}date features until long term support
and stability can be verified.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to this branch with

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git checkout master
git pull origin master
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{developer version}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note the developer version should have been tested and semi\sphinxhyphen{}stable but
not ready for full sets of processing and definitely not for release for
non\sphinxhyphen{}developers or for data put on archives. Some changes may not be
in this version that are in the working version.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to this branch with

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git checkout developer
git pull origin developer
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{working version}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note the working version will be the most up\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}date version but has not been
tested for stability \sphinxhyphen{} use at own risk.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to this branch with

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git checkout working
git pull origin working
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Prerequisites}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:prerequisites}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-prerequisites}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
APERO is coded using \sphinxhref{https://www.python.org/download/releases/3.0/}{python 3}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently we recommend python 3.9 (however 3.7 and 3.8 are supported).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please do not use python 2 with APERO.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please use the requirements file to install the exact required modules
i.e. from the git hub directory

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pip install \PYGZhy{}r requirements\PYGZus{}current.txt
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Some developer tools require additional modules. Please use the
requirements\_developer.txt for these (This can be done at any time
after the installation process to use the tools).
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Please make sure you are in the correct environment (especially if
using conda). If using conda it is worth doing a \sphinxtitleref{which pip} to
make sure your pip is installing the python modules to the
correct environment (and not, for example, your base or system
environment).
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{Setup}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:setup}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-setup}}

\paragraph{Possible pre\sphinxhyphen{}installation step}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:possible-pre-installation-step}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When doing a full reduction it may be useful to have a static raw directory
(e.g. if a raw directory has files coming in from observations / synced to other servers).

\sphinxAtStartPar
For a static full reduction it is preferable not to add new raw files during processing
(i.e. it requires time to update database, templates could need to change with new observations etc)

\sphinxAtStartPar
For this reason a script \sphinxtitleref{copyraw.py} exists i.e.
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python setup/copyraw.py \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}indir /path/to/full/raw/dir \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}outdir /path/to/new/symlink/dir \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}do\PYGZus{}symlink
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
By default it create symlinks but these can be turned off and hard copies can be created with the following:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python setup/copyraw.py \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}indir /path/to/full/raw/dir \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}outdir /path/to/new/symlink/dir \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}do\PYGZus{}copy
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}


\paragraph{Run the installation script}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:run-the-installation-script}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Change to the \sphinxtitleref{\{DRS\_ROOT\}} directory

\sphinxAtStartPar
Run the installation script
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python setup/install.py \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}name\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
where \{{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PROFILE}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{PROFILE}}}}\} is a short descriptive name for a setup (you can have multiple
profiles with one installation)

\sphinxAtStartPar
e.g.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python setup/install.py \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}name\PYG{o}{=}setup\PYGZus{}njc\PYGZus{}200903
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}


\paragraph{Step\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}step guide}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:step-by-step-guide}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Follow the step\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}step guide:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A: User configuration path

This is the path where your configuration will be saved. If it doesn’t exist you will be prompted to create it.
(This will be referred to as {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_UCONFIG}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_UCONFIG}}}} from now on (default is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/home/user/apero/\sphinxstyleemphasis{PROFILE}}})
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
B: Instrument settings
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Install {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-1}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{INSTRUMENT}}}}.
If yes it will install the instrument if not then it will not install the instrument. Currently only SPIRou is supported
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
C: Set up paths
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first question will ask  whether to set up paths individually. If \sphinxtitleref{{[}Y{]}es}
it will allow you to set each path separately (i.e. for raw, tmp, reduced, calibDB etc). If \sphinxtitleref{{[}N{]}o}
you will just set one path and all folders (raw, tmp, reduced, calibDB etc)) will be created under this directory.
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
D: Setting the directory/directories
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Will prompt you to enter the directory path/paths (will ask you for each if you answered that paths be set up individually in step C above.
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
E: Clean install
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you type {[}Y{]}es you will be prompted (later) to reset the directories this means any previous data in these directories will be removed. Note you can always say later to individual cases.
\end{quote}

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Resetting a directory will remove all files/sub\sphinxhyphen{}directories from within these folders
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A to E will repeat for all installable instruments (To step up just one use the \sphinxtitleref{\textendash{}instrument} argument
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{Activating the APERO profile}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:activating-the-apero-profile}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-activate}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To activate an apero profile you need to source the \sphinxtitleref{\{DRS\_UCONGIG\}/\{PROFILE\}.\{SYSTEM\}}.setup script.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Details of this should be in green at the end of the installation process

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for bash:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}.bash.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for tcsh/csh/sh
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}.sh.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
e.g. with bash and our example profile above:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{source} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{PROFILE}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sh}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{setup}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We strongly recommend setting up a alias for this

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for bash (i.e. in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bashrc}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.profile}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bash\_aliases}}):
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{alias} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}source \PYGZob{}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYGZcb{}/\PYGZob{}PROFILE\PYGZcb{}.bash.setup\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for tcsh/csh/sh  (i.e. in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.tcshrc}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.cshrc}} etc)
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{alias} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}source \PYGZob{}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYGZcb{}/\PYGZob{}PROFILE\PYGZcb{}.sh.setup\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This must be done every time one wishes to use APERO (and must be
done after one activates the conda environment

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{conda activate apero\sphinxhyphen{}env}

\sphinxAtStartPar
One could add these both to automatically happen in a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bashrc}} but
we recommend activating each time.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Following on from typing this command you should see a splash screen validating the
installation and letting you know everything is good to run APERO recipes and tools.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{apero_splash}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For details about the splash screen click \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{here}.


\subsubsection{Updating from github}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:updating-from-github}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-update}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Choose a branch (as in {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation-choose-branch}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Choose branch}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Update the branch (pull from github)
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git pull origin \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}branch\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Make sure you are in an APERO profile

\PYG{n+nb}{source} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/setup.bash.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
or if you have it aliased

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
e.g.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source} /home/user/apero/setup\PYGZus{}njc\PYGZus{}200903/setup.bash.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
or if you have it aliased

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
setup\PYGZus{}njc\PYGZus{}200903
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Update using the installation script
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python setup/install.py \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will use all current settings and update the


\subsection{Using APERO}
\label{\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:using-apero}}\label{\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:using-apero-default}}\label{\detokenize{main/default/using_apero::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The user scripts to reduce data are referred to as ‘recipes’.

\sphinxAtStartPar
From a coding point of view this due to the fact that they literally list
the steps (where each step is a function or set of functions).

\sphinxAtStartPar
By design recipes are kept to a bare minimum of code and all heavy functionality
is done in the functions that are called in the recipes.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently supported instruments are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
SPIRou (See the section on recipes {\hyperref[\detokenize{auto/recipe_definitions/spirou/recipes:recipes-spirou}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}})

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are two ways to use APERO:
\begin{quote}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using recipes individually

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using the processing script to automatically generate batches of recipe
runs (based on provided run files)

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
both of these require installation (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}})
and activating a profile (see the next section {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:activating-apero-profile}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}})
\end{quote}


\subsubsection{Activating the APERO profile}
\label{\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:activating-the-apero-profile}}\label{\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:activating-apero-profile}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To activate an apero profile you need to source the \sphinxtitleref{\{DRS\_UCONGIG\}/\{PROFILE\}.\{SYSTEM\}}.setup script.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Details of this should be in green at the end of the installation process

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for bash:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}.bash.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for tcsh/csh/sh
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}/\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}.sh.setup
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
e.g. with bash and our example profile above:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{source} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{PROFILE}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sh}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{setup}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We strongly recommend setting up a alias for this

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for bash (i.e. in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bashrc}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.profile}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bash\_aliases}}):
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{alias} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}source \PYGZob{}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYGZcb{}/\PYGZob{}PROFILE\PYGZcb{}.bash.setup\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for tcsh/csh/sh  (i.e. in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.tcshrc}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.cshrc}} etc)
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{alias} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}PROFILE\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}source \PYGZob{}DRS\PYGZus{}UCONFIG\PYGZcb{}/\PYGZob{}PROFILE\PYGZcb{}.sh.setup\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This must be done every time one wishes to use APERO (and must be
done after one activates the conda environment

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{conda activate apero\sphinxhyphen{}env}

\sphinxAtStartPar
One could add these both to automatically happen in a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.bashrc}} but
we recommend activating each time.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Following on from typing this command you should see a splash screen validating the
installation and letting you know everything is good to run APERO recipes and tools.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{apero_splash}.png}

\subsection{APERO in depth}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:apero-in-depth}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:deep}}\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep::doc}}

\subsubsection{The base module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-base-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The base module contains very basic functionality and is kept at a bare
minimum, in general sub\sphinxhyphen{}modules and scripts in here cannot use other APERO
functionality (hence the less functionality in here the better).


\subsubsection{The core module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-core-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is where the core functionality is stored. In general all core functionality
should be instrument independent, however there is a separate sub\sphinxhyphen{}module specifically
for instrument dependent code (and default settings).


\subsubsection{The io module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-io-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the input/output module. In general these should not use any functionality
from APERO and instead are modules that have independent pieces of code or use
other python modules related to the input and output of files (reading, writing etc.).


\subsubsection{The language module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-language-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module has all the functionality referring to the language database (except
the database itself which is a base module). The language functionality refers to
the use of the print codes and relating them to a specific language \sphinxhyphen{} i.e. no user
text should be written into the codes instead should be referred to via codes to
text in the langauge database.


\subsubsection{The plotting module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-plotting-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All plotting functionality should be located in here and called from any recipe
when required. In theory no plotting code should be located elsewhere in APERO.


\subsubsection{The Recipe module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-recipe-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is where the recipes for each instrument are stored.


\subsubsection{The science module}
\label{\detokenize{main/general/deep:the-science-module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The science module contains all functionality related to astrophysics
algorithms. It is divided into sub\sphinxhyphen{}modules as follows: calibration
functionality (“calib”), extraction functionality (“extract”), polarimetry
functionality (“polar”), pre\sphinxhyphen{}processing functionality (“preprocessing”),
atmospheric correction functionality (“telluric”) and radial velocity
functionality (“velocity”).

\paragraph{Preprocessing functionality}
\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:preprocessing-functionality}}\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:science-preprocessing}}\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing::doc}}

\subparagraph{Raw file header fixing}
\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:raw-file-header-fixing}}\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:science-preprocessing-header-fixes}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The header fixes are controlled via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.core.drs\_file.fix\_header()}}
which in turn uses the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PseudoConst}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{PseudoConst}}}} method \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{HEADER\_FIXES()}}.
This is defined for each instrument
(e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseduo\_const.HEADER\_FIXES()}})

\sphinxAtStartPar
For SPIRou the current header fixes are as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
clean object name (via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseduo\_const.clean\_obj\_name()}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
get target type (via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseduo\_const.get\_trg\_type()}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
get mid observation time (via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseduo\_const.get\_mid\_obs\_time()}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
get the raw data type (via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseduo\_const.get\_dprtype()}})

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Raw file identification}
\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:raw-file-identification}}\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:science-preprocessing-file-identification}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This takes a given input file and checks it against the instrument {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-file-definitions}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{file\sphinxhyphen{}definitions}}}}.
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-file-definitions}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{file\sphinxhyphen{}definitions}}}} give all the criteria by which an input file can be
matched as a specific drs file type.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is done via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.science.preprocessing.identification.drs\_infile\_id()}}
which in turn calls \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.core.drs\_file.id\_drs\_file()}} and returns
a tuple \sphinxhyphen{} whether the file was found in the instruments definition and the
drs file type ({\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DrsInputFile}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DrsInputFile}}}} instance)


\subparagraph{Gaia ID and object finding}
\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:gaia-id-and-object-finding}}\label{\detokenize{main/science/preprocessing:science-preprocessing-object-finding}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We assume the header either has a Gaia ID column (defined by the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-2}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_GAIA\_ID}}}} keyword)
or a valid object name (defined by the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-3}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_OBJECTNAME}}}} keyword).

\sphinxAtStartPar
We then attempt to resolve parameters in the following order
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{If {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-OBJ_LIST_RESOLVE_FROM_DATABASE}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{OBJ\_LIST\_RESOLVE\_FROM\_DATABASE}}}} From a local database}] \leavevmode\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\alph}{enumii}{enumiii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
based on Gaia ID

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
if Gaia ID is not found based on object name (from a list of aliases)

\end{enumerate}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-OBJ_LIST_RESOLVE_FROM_COORDS}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{OBJ\_LIST\_RESOLVE\_FROM\_COORDS}}}} and if object was not found in local database but we have a Gaia ID then we
get the Gaia parameters from the online Gaia catalog \sphinxhyphen{} if an object if found
the local database is updated.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-OBJ_LIST_RESOLVE_FROM_GLIST}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{OBJ\_LIST\_RESOLVE\_FROM\_GLIST}}}} and if we did not have a Gaia id
we then use a google sheet of known objects to match object names and Gaia
ids (we can also add extra aliases here). If a Gaia ID/object name
combination is found we then cross\sphinxhyphen{}match against the online Gaia catalog to
get the Gaia parameters and again update the local database.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-OBJ_LIST_RESOLVE_FROM_COORDS}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{OBJ\_LIST\_RESOLVE\_FROM\_COORDS}}}} is True we then use the coordinates
from the file header to cross\sphinxhyphen{}match with Gaia directly and again the local
database is updated.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If the Gaia id is still unknown we default to the astrophysical parameters
in the header.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the local object database should be updated before doing a full
reprocessing and updating at any other time (other than adding new objects as above)
may lead to inconsistent data sets.

\subsubsection{apero\_astrometric}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM:apero-astrometric}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM:user-tools-default-astrom}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: ASTROM

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero astrometrics recipe allows one to add an object or a set of objects
to the astrometrics database (pending list) \sphinxhyphen{} to allow APERO to get the best
possible coordinates, proper motions and parallax as possible.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The online database \sphinxhref{https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1dOogfEwC7wAagjVFdouB1Y1JdF9Eva4uDW6CTZ8x2FM/edit?usp=sharing}{can be viewed here}. (but not edited).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first thing that is checked is whether the object (or one of its aliases)
exists in the database. If it does the code skips this objects.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
An object can be forced to be updated with the \textendash{}overwrite command.
This is only recommended if an object currently in the astrometric
database is deemed to be suspicious.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once an object has been found not to be present currently in the database the
user is asked whether they with to add the object to the database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero astrometrics recipe then cross\sphinxhyphen{}matches the name against SIMBAD, and
tries to update the astrometrics with the best possible proper motions (see
section 1.1 below) it then produces a print out to the screen similar to the
following:

where:
\begin{itemize}

and puntucation removed) used throughout APERO.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

throughout APERO.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

where they come from.
.. note:: “COORD\_SOURCE” should match “PM\_SOURCE” (see section 1.1 below)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{itemize}

\item {}

(normally a bib code reference)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
“SPT” and “SPT\_SOURCE” are the spectral type and source \textendash{} if available
(normally a bib code reference)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
EPOCH is the JD time of the coordinates and proper motion (see section 1.1 below)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
“Jmag”, “Hmag” and “Kmag” are the J/H and K magnitudes from SIMBAD

\end{itemize}

\subparagraph{1.1 SIMBAD, coordinates and proper motions}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM:simbad-coordinates-and-proper-motions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Crossmatching an object name with SIMBAD is a great way to find the correct
astrophysical object against a list of aliases and a large database of
coordinates, motions and distances. However the coordinates given by
SIMBAD are at 2000.0 but the proper motions are not. Therefore we only
use SIMBAD to get a list of aliases for a certain astrophysical object and
check against a few proper motion catalogues (matching to the ID from SIMBAD)
to get coordinates that match the proper motion epoch.

against these proper motion catalogues and obtain coordinates (ra and dec) that
match the same epoch (i.e. for Gaia DR2 2015.5). We only match enough catalogues
to provide one set of none\sphinxhyphen{}null coordaintes and proper motions.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
HIP

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If an astrophysical object does not have an alias in any of these catalogues
we return a warning and skip this target.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once all targets have been matched (or skipped) the online database is updated
(in the pending list) waiting the verification of administrators.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
that if a astrophyiscal object is in the pending list but not in the
main list it will be used in APERO by default (assuming users allow updates
from the database). If an astrophyiscal object is both in the main and pending
lists, the pending list entry will NOT be used. The main list will be
updated at specific times deemed by the administrators (to minimize
inconsistencies between large redictions whereby changing a targets astrometrics
could induce differences between unreduced and already reduced observations).
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subparagraph{1.2 APERO naming convenions}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_ASTROM:apero-naming-convenions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
APERO will remove spaces (replace with an underscore)
APERO will remove “\sphinxhyphen{}” and replace with an “M”
APERO will remove “+” and replace with a “P”
APERO will force upper case

\sphinxAtStartPar
This means some objects will have poor names or names that are seen as unique when they should not be
i.e.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
WASP\sphinxhyphen{}107b \textendash{}\textgreater{} WASPM107B

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
WASP107b  \textendash{}\textgreater{} WASP107B

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
WASP 107b \textendash{}\textgreater{} WASP\_107B

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
WASP107B \textendash{}\textgreater{} WASP107B

\end{itemize}
\begin{description}
\item[{Therefore during the astrometrics code you have the oppotunity to}] \leavevmode\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\alph}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
define the name apero will use (any white space, “\sphinxhyphen{}”, “+” and punctuation will be removed as above)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
add to the aliases (add as many combinations as you feel is necessary to describe the target) i.e. add both WASP 107 and WASP107 and WASP\sphinxhyphen{}107

\end{enumerate}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Do not use b, c, d for planets \sphinxhyphen{} name by the star, multiple\sphinxhyphen{}star\sphinxhyphen{}systems use A,B,C,D

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
we do not change the raw file headers so all original object names will be preserved
(i.e. with SPIRou “OBJNAME” and “OBJECT” are preserved)
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsubsection{apero\_explorer}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_EXPLO:apero-explorer}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_EXPLO:user-tools-default-explo}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_EXPLO::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_EXPLO:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: EXPLO

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_explorer recipe is designed as a graphical user interface (GUI) between the user and the
various databases that APERO uses. The script downloads a static copy of the SQL database,
changes are not updated or saved in real time (but can be updated/saved by selecting the
correct menu options).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Tables within the database currently accessible with the explorer are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
calib: The calibration database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
tellu: The telluric database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
index: The file index database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
log: The logger database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
object: The object astrometric database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
lang: The text and language database

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GUI allows the user to:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Do File operations:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open a pickle file to replace the current database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Import a csv file to replace the current database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Save a pickle file of the current database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Export a csv file of the current database

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Edit the current database}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Find and replace a string with another value

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Filter rows by a certain criteria

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add rows and columns

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Table operations}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
refresh the current database (with updates since launching the GUI)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Save changes for the current database to the main database

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clean strings

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Remove formatting

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Get some information of the table formatting

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
No changes will be saved unless you use the “Table\textgreater{}Save to Database” option
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We do not recommend changing any of the database entries without good reason
and without talking to the developers
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In addition to the GUI explorer, apero\_explorer can be run in “flag mode”.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This recipes both the \textendash{}recipe and \textendash{}flagnum arguments to be used.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}explorer}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{recipe}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{PP} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{flagnum}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{21}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Gives the binary flags for “preprocessing” (shortname: PP) when the decimal
representation of the flags is set to a value of (21)

\sphinxAtStartPar
The output for apero\_explorer is then as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{Flag} \PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PP}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{recipe} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}preprocess\PYGZus{}spirou}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py}
  \PYG{n}{IN\PYGZus{}PARALLEL}         \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
  \PYG{n}{RUNNING}             \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
  \PYG{n}{ENDED}               \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
  \PYG{n}{OBJ}                 \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
  \PYG{n}{QCPASSED}            \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Showing that the flag number 21 (binary 10101) corresponds to these flags being
true or false.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note the flags are specific to a specific recipe and thus the \textendash{}recipe argument
must be used.

\subsubsection{apero\_get}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GET:apero-get}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GET:user-tools-default-get}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GET::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GET:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: GET

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_get recipe is a quick and efficient way of copying (or linking to) data from the
main data directories of apero.

\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_get allow the user to select a specific file or files based on:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
object name: (using the \textendash{}objnames argument), this select only files with
the given object name

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
output file type: (using the \textendash{}outtypes argument), this selects only files
with the given output (see file definitions, i.e. {\hyperref[\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/spirou/files:spirou-file-def}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{file definitions for SPIROU}}}})
(the name column) for the specific values for each file

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
data types (using the \textendash{}dprtypes argument), this similarly to output file type
relates to the input file type (see pre\sphinxhyphen{}processing file definitions, i.e. {\hyperref[\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/spirou/files:spirou-pp-file}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{file definitions for SPIROU}}}})
(the HDR{[}DPRTYPE{]} column) for the specific values for each file

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
fibers \sphinxhyphen{} the fibers to use (i.e. for spirou some combination of AB, A, B, C)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The user can also set the output directory where files should be copied to and
whether the copied files are just symlinks or full copies of the data.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We recommend running with \textendash{}test the first time this is used to make
sure you have the files you want (and check whether all the options worked)
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_get recipe also allows quick copying of the full raw data set (or symlinks) this is useful when doing a full
reduction and wanting a consistent dataset (where a normal raw directory may be getting new files every day)
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}get}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{raw} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{symlink} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{outpath} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{home}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{test}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{apero}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{files}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{raw}\PYG{o}{/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\subsubsection{apero\_go}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GO:apero-go}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GO:user-tools-default-go}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GO::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_GO:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: GO

\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_go is used to to find current paths set by current profile.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The paths are set via the user\_config.py files (in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_UCONFIG}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_UCONFIG}}}} directory).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Available paths (reffered to {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-block_kind}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{block\_kind}}}}) are:
raw, tmp, red, calib, tellu, out, assets, plot, run and log.

\subsubsection{apero\_listing}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LIST:apero-listing}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LIST:user-tools-default-list}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LIST::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LIST:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: LIST

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_listing recipe re\sphinxhyphen{}builds the index database.
It has various ways of doing this:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-observation-directory}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory}}}} (using the \textendash{}obs\_dir argument) to select one observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-block_kind}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{block\_kind}}}} (using the \textendash{}block\_kind argument) to select either “raw”, “tmp” or “red” data directory

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
excluding observation directories: these directories will be ignored
(multiple observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories should be comma separated)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
including observation directories: these directories will be included and everything else ignored
(multiple observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories should be comma separated)

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{apero\_precheck}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PRECHECK:apero-precheck}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PRECHECK:user-tools-default-precheck}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PRECHECK::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PRECHECK:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: PRECHECK

\sphinxAtStartPar
The precheck recipe allows the user to check the current raw data stored in the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_RAW}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_RAW}}}} directory. These checks are split into two parts a
file check and a object check. The checks are based on a supplied {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-run-ini-file}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file}}}}
which controls which recipes are and are not being used for a specific apero\_processing
run.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The file checks are as follows:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number of calibrations in each {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-observation-directory}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory}}}} and whether
this meets the minimum number of calibrations required for the sequence
defined in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-run-ini-file}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file}}}}. A list of observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories that
will cause problems due to missing calibrations is printed during the
precheck recipe run.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note if the observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory is sorted by observation night
this will correctly flag if there are nights without calibrations
within +/\sphinxhyphen{} the required time frame (controlled by \DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{MAX\_CALIB\_DTIME})
but will not be able to assess whether calibrations pass quality
control during processing.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number of science and telluric files found (note if the run\sphinxhyphen{}in\sphinxhyphen{}file has
\sphinxtitleref{USE\_ENGINEERING = False} any observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory without science files will
be ignored by the apero\_processing recipe. The list of engineering observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories
is also printed during the precheck recipe run.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The object check is done as follows:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The object database is checked for all valid entries (and any ignore entries)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
All unique object names in raw files are checked against the object database
object names (and associated aliases of each object name)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any object name not in the current database and not in the current ignore list
are printed for the user to decide whether object must be added to the
database or left to use the header values

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Objects are only required in the database for accurate BERV calculations,
as such only objects required precision radial velocity must be in the
database, however we recommend all objects be added.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\paragraph{2. Schematic}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PRECHECK:schematic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
No schematic set


\paragraph{3. Usage}

\subsubsection{apero\_processing}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PROC:apero-processing}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PROC:user-tools-default-proc}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PROC::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PROC:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: PROC

\sphinxAtStartPar
The processing script is the recommended way to run the reduction.
It takes a {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-run-ini-file}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file}}}} which contains parameters specific to the users
needs for that processing session. Based on these run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file parameters and the
raw data (stored in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_RAW}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_RAW}}}} directory) a set of recipes or a
\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequences} will determine which recipes are run for which raw files.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}files are an important part of the processing script and have
many options to control the processing run.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Some of the following arguments can also be added to the command\sphinxhyphen{}line or python function call
(see section 4)
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Options are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
RUN\_NAME: the name of the run

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
SEND\_EMAIL: whether to send an email on start/finish

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
EMAIL\_ADDRESS: the email address to send an email to

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
RUN\_OBS\_DIR: Whether to limit processing to a single {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-observation-directory}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
EXCLUDE\_OBS\_DIRS: Whether to ignore certain observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
INCLUDE\_OBS\_DIRS: Whether to limit processing to a set of observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
PI\_NAMES: Whether to limit processing to a single or list of PI\_NAMES (must match the header key {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_PI_NAME}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_PI\_NAME}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
MASTER\_OBS\_DIR: The {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-observation-directory}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory}}}} to use as the master
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
this should not be changed in general but does require calibrations from this night to be
present in the raw directory.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently we do not support multiple master\_obs\_dir and a full reduction should never mix
different master observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\end{quote}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{CORES: The number of cores to use}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This should always be at least N\sphinxhyphen{}1 less than the total number of cores available
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
STOP\_AT\_EXCEPTION: The processing code will not continue past an error and will stop

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{TEST\_RUN: Runs the processing script without running any recipes}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is highly recommended, please check that you are reducing the expected data before running
without TEST\_RUN = False
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{USE\_ENGINEERING: If True engineering observation\sphinxhyphen{}directories (those without science observation).}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In general we do not recommend to reduce these nights as they may
reduce the quality of reduced data
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
TRIGGER\_RUN: For use in online reductions only

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
USE\_REJECTLIST: If True checks that odometer code aren’t already flagged as bad files

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{RECAL\_TEMPLATES: If True recalculates the templates that are already present.}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This should only be done when re\sphinxhyphen{}reducing all data for a single object.
Recalculating the template for only new observations will greatly affect RV precision
and we do not recommend doing any time series analysis with a varying template.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A template hash key is available in the header of files that have used a template. If
unsure check that the template hash matches for all observations.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{UPDATE\_OBJ\_DATABASE: If True the locally stored object database is updated from online.}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Do not do this unless you are re\sphinxhyphen{}reducing all the data. If the object database
has updated parameters this could affect RV precision (as the BERV calculation may
change).
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{RUN\_XXX: For each recipe (or recipe in a sequence) there is a {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-shortname}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{shortname}}}} associated with it. A user can}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
turn on and off recipes within a sequence without having to create a new sequence.
i.e. setting \sphinxtitleref{RUN\_PP = False} will turn of the \sphinxtitleref{PP} recipe (apero\_preprocessing) all recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs in an
apero\_processing run will be skipped.

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{SKIP\_XXX: Similar to RUN\_XXX there is a {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-shortname}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{shortname}}}} that can be skipped, if and only if the recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run can be}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
found in the logging database (i.e. all required arguments are identical) and it has successfully completed
in a previous apero\_processing run, or when run individually

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{TELLURIC\_TARGETS: A filter for certain recipes that use hot star observations to only use certain hot star object names}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
(and thus only use certain observations). The default value is “All” which uses all telluric objects
in a pre\sphinxhyphen{}configured list of telluric object.

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{SCIENCE\_TARGETS: A filter for certain recipes that use science observations. Using this a user can only reduced data}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
for a single object name or a list of object names (separated by a comma).
For example if one sets \sphinxtitleref{SCIENCE\_TARGETS=Gl699} and had \sphinxtitleref{RUN\_EXTOBJ=True} only extractions of Gl699
would be reduced

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The very last piece of information required is the sequences (or individual recipe runs) that are required.
The should be numbered id00000, id00001, id00002 etc and should only contain an individual recipe run (with all correct
arguments) or a sequence name. For sequence names see the sequences page for an instrument
(e.g. for spirou click {\hyperref[\detokenize{auto/recipe_sequences/spirou/sequences:sequences-spirou}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}}).


\paragraph{2. Schematic}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_PROC:schematic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar

\subsubsection{apero\_reset}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_RESET:apero-reset}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_RESET:user-tools-default-reset}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_RESET::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_RESET:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: RESET

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_reset recipe resets all (or some) of the data directories defined by the user

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Be very careful using this recipe, you can delete a lot of data very quickly
There is no backup generated once apero\_reset has been run.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For a normal run no arguments are required.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The reset recipe will guide you through all the data directories that can be reset and ask
whether you want to reset the directores. You must type “yes” to reset a directory.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If an directory is already empty it will be skipped.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The data directories that can be reset are as follows:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Assets directory
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This resets the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_ASSETS}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_ASSETS}}}} directory (removes all files, and all databases)
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Tmp directory
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This resets the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_WORKING}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_WORKING}}}} directory (removes all files) and the index database
with {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-block_kind}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{block\_kind}}}} = “tmp”
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Reduced directory
\begin{quote}

\subsubsection{apero\_stats}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT:apero-stats}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT:user-tools-default-stat}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: STAT

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero stats file is usually run during or after a apero\_processing run.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are three modes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
timing mode: (using \textendash{}mode=timing)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
quality control mode: (using \textendash{}mode=qc)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
error mode: (using \textendash{}mode=error)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the \sphinxtitleref{\textendash{}plog} argument is used (with the absolute path to a apero log file group)
then only the stats for that apero\_processing run are used


\subparagraph{1.1 Timing mode}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT:timing-mode}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This mode takes all the \DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs} in the logger database (at this point in time) and measures
various timing stats for each recipe.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
timing mode has to read and sort all log entries. This can take
quite some time to get the stats of a full run of data
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \textendash{}plog argument is not used for timing mode
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The stats are printed per recipe (named by the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-shortname}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{shortname}}}}) and are as
follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Mean time: the mean time for recipes of this shortname +/\sphinxhyphen{} the standard deviation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Median time: the median time for recipes of this shortname +/\sphinxhyphen{} the standard deviation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The range in times (minimum and maximum) for recipes of this shortname

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number of runs (\sphinxtitleref{Nruns}) of this recipe attempted

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{The total time recipes of this shortname were running (end of last recipe run minus start of first recipe run)}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The total time is only correct if all recipes of this shortname were run without interruption with no
other recipe runs between \sphinxhyphen{} this is the standard apero\_processing approach but may not be true if
analysing multiple log entries
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The total cpu time the recipe of this shortname were running (the duration) note if all recipes of this shortname
ran in a single block this should be the time taken if done on a single core

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
efficiency \sphinxtitleref{(total cpu time)/(total time)}, perfect efficiency would give a value equal to the number of cores used
(however a perfect efficiency is impossible)

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If \sphinxtitleref{Nruns} is less than the number of cores the total cpu time and total time should be the same and the
efficiency should tend towards (or be exactly 1).
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As well as the stats, after all stats have printed a histogram of each recipe with over 10 recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs is plotted.
This shows this distribution of timings for each shortname.

\sphinxAtStartPar
1.2 Quality control mode
\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}\textasciicircum{}6

\sphinxAtStartPar
This mode takes all the \DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs} in the logger database and prints statistics on the quality control
recorded in each recipe (if present).

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
quality control mode has to read and sort all log entries. This can take
quite some time to get the stats of a full run of data
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \textendash{}plog argument is not used for timing mode
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The stats are printed per recipe (named by the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-shortname}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{shortname}}}}) and are as
follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number passed compared to the number that finished in total

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number failed compared to the number that finished in total

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Mean/Median/Max/Min and criteria of failure for each quality control

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number that were still “running” when this report was made (should be zero if not apero\_processing is running)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number that ended successfully (i.e. did not encouter an error or exception \sphinxhyphen{} handled or otherwise)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As well as this for each shortname that has quality control a plot is produced. This plot should show N+1 panels,
where N is the number of quality control criteria. The top panel shows the global pass/fail/ended statistics
(taking into account all quality control criteria). The other panels show (if numeric) a value of the quality control
criteria measured for each recipe run with that shortname as a function of observation date
(from header key {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_MID_OBS_TIME}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_MID\_OBS\_TIME}}}}). These values should be in blue and in red (as a dashed line) compared to
a logic threshold (i.e. points above or below, depending on the criteria fail or pass).

\sphinxAtStartPar
This process is repeated for each shortname and graphs and or stats are shown if quality control criteria are available
and numeric.


\subparagraph{1.3 Error mode}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_STAT:error-mode}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The error mode takes all errors caught during apero\_processing runs.
Using the \textendash{}plog argument one can select just a single apero\_processing run.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
the only log files that should be used as an argument to \textendash{}plog are in
the {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_MSG}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_MSG}}}} directory, specifically \sphinxtitleref{./tool/other/APEROL\sphinxhyphen{}PID\sphinxhyphen{}\{PID\}\sphinxhyphen{}apero\_processing.log} files
(there should be one of these log files for each time apero\_processing was run) where {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PID}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{PID}}}} is the unique
PID for that apero\_processing run.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The error mode groups all found errors into files based on the apero error codes given (i.e. EXX\sphinxhyphen{}XXX\sphinxhyphen{}XXXXX) and also
groups any errors that do not have an apero error code (unexpected exceptions) by the last line of text of that
exception (generally these are the same for the same exception).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Statistic of these are printed to the screen and a directory is added to the
\sphinxtitleref{DRS\_DATA\_MSG/report/APEROL\sphinxhyphen{}PID\sphinxhyphen{}\{PID\}\_apero\_processing/} directory.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Files are saved as the error code: E\_XX\_XXX\_XXXXX.log or if they were unexpected exceptions with a E\_UNHANDLE\_YYYYY.log
where YYYYY increases from 0 up to the maximum number of unique unexpected execptions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each of these error log files contains all errors that match

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}================================================}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZob{}i\PYGZcb{} / \PYGZob{}total\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} RUNSTRING = program.py \PYGZob{}arguments\PYGZcb{} \PYGZob{}options\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}=================================================}

\PYG{n}{ERROR} \PYG{n}{MSG} \PYG{n}{LINE} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
\PYG{n}{ERROR} \PYG{n}{MSG} \PYG{n}{LINE} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
\PYG{n}{ERROR} \PYG{n}{MSG} \PYG{n}{LINE} \PYG{n}{N}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Where i is the nth error of this type, total is the total number of errors of this type

\subsubsection{apero\_trigger}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER:apero-trigger}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER:user-tools-default-trigger}}\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER::doc}}

\paragraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: TRIGGER

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero trigger runs continuiously and tries to accurately reduces night data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It requires a master night to be processed BEFORE starting.


\subparagraph{How it works}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER:how-it-works}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
It works as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
copies files from a “live directory” into a sym\sphinxhyphen{}linked directory
(the live directory is defined be \textendash{}indir, the sym\sphinxhyphen{}lined directory
is the raw directory defined in installation \textendash{} i.e. DRS\_DATA\_RAW)

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{tries to figure out what has been done previously}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
this is done in two steps

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{first step: calibrations}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
it uses the log database and the \sphinxtitleref{trigger\_night\_calibrun.ini}
file to work out (per obs\_dir) whether at least one of  each
recipe has been run (it counts QC failures as done)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
if all steps are not complete it runs \sphinxtitleref{apero processing} with the
\sphinxtitleref{trigger\_night\_calibrun.ini} run.ini file with the standard
skips in \sphinxtitleref{apero\_processing}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_processing will stop if a recipe finds no runs (this is
only true in \sphinxtitleref{TRIGGER\_RUN=True} mode

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{second step: science}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
this step is only done once all calibrations are deemed to be
completed

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
it uses the log database, index database and the
\sphinxtitleref{trigger\_night\_scirun.ini} file to work out whether all recipes
with science DPRTYPES have been run (per obs\_dir)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
if there aren’t the same number of raw science files as recipe
runs (in the log database) it will attempt to re\sphinxhyphen{}run
\sphinxtitleref{apero processing} with the \sphinxtitleref{trigger\_night\_scirun.ini} run.ini
file with the standard skips in \sphinxtitleref{apero\_processing}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_processing will stop if a recipe finds no runs (this is
only true in \sphinxtitleref{TRIGGER\_RUN=True} mode

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Caveats}
\label{\detokenize{auto/tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_TRIGGER:caveats}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
results may not be optimal \sphinxhyphen{} we recommended running all nights together in
an offline manner (after having all nights) for optimal results, for example:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
calibrations may be sub\sphinxhyphen{}optimal (missing/using wrong night etc)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
telluric correction may not be using all hot stars

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
templates may be sub\sphinxhyphen{}optimal

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
polar recipes cannot be produced online

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A master night must be run before running \sphinxtitleref{apero\_trigger.py}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Adding files for older nights after newer nights could result in unwanted behaviour
(especially when it comes to calibrations)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Removing files may result in new calibrations being generated with less calibrations
than before (apero\_processing skip only works with the same number of files)
and apero will use the most recently reduced calibration

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Once calibrations are finished for a night remove/adding calibration files will not
re\sphinxhyphen{}trigger the calibration sequence (unless \textendash{}reset is used)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
All obs\_dir and files in the \textendash{}indir will be processed, use \textendash{}ignore to remove
certain obs\_dirs from the obs\_dirs list

\end{itemize}

installation process (or updated manually in the files afterwards) are correct to at least
setup APERO.

to when any recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run is started.

\paragraph{1.2 APERO definition of DRSMODE}

For “DRSMODE” we use the following header keys
\begin{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
SBRHB1\_P

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
SBRHB2\_P

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
and DRSMODE is defined as following:
\end{quote}

\paragraph{1.3 APERO definition of TRG\_TYPE}
\label{\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/spirou/files:apero-definition-of-trg-type}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
TRG\_TYPE may be in the header, in which case it is used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If TRG\_TYPE is not in header we assign it based on the following keys:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
OBSTYPE

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
OBJECT

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
OBJNAME

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then TRG\_TYPE is set as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If OBSTYPE is not “OBJECT” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If OBSTYPE is “OBJECT” and “SKY” in OBJECT or OBJNAME then TRG\_TYPE = ‘SKY’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
else if OBSTYPE is “OBJECT” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘TARGET’

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{6.2 Definition of WAVE\_FILES}
\label{\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/spirou/files:definition-of-wave-files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Here “WAVE\_FILES” denotes either a wave solution from the
nightly solution (WAVE\_NIGHT)
or
the master wave solution (WAVESOL\_MASTER)
or
the default wave solution (WAVESOL\_DEFAULT)

\paragraph{1.2 APERO definition of TRG\_TYPE}
\label{\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/nirps_he/files:apero-definition-of-trg-type}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
TRG\_TYPE may be in the header, in which case it is used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If TRG\_TYPE is not in header we assign it based on the following key:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then TRG\_TYPE is set as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE contains “SKY” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘SKY’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE contains “OBJECT” or “STAR” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘TARGET’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Else TRG\_TYPE = ‘’

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{1.2 APERO definition of TRG\_TYPE}
\label{\detokenize{auto/file_definitions/nirps_ha/files:apero-definition-of-trg-type}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
TRG\_TYPE may be in the header, in which case it is used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If TRG\_TYPE is not in header we assign it based on the following key:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then TRG\_TYPE is set as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE contains “SKY” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘SKY’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If HIERARCH ESO DPR TYPE contains “OBJECT” or “STAR” then TRG\_TYPE = ‘TARGET’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Else TRG\_TYPE = ‘’

\end{itemize}

\section{Developer how to guide}
\label{\detokenize{main/developer/main_dev:developer-how-to-guide}}\label{\detokenize{main/developer/main_dev:dev-main}}\label{\detokenize{main/developer/main_dev::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below is a guide for those developing APERO for the current set of instruments
and for future instruments.


\subsection{Developer tools}
\label{\detokenize{main/developer/main_dev:developer-tools}}\label{\detokenize{main/developer/main_dev:dev-main-tools}}

\subsubsection{Dev tools}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/dev_tools:dev-tools}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/dev_tools:dev-tools-default}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/dev_tools::doc}}\begin{description}
\item[{This section describes all the default dev tools to use with APERO.}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
For information on how to run these dev tools (either individually or with the processing tools) see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/default/using_apero:using-apero-default}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}}.

\end{description}


\paragraph{apero\_changelog}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:apero-changelog}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:dev-tools-default-clog}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG::doc}}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: CLOG

\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_changelog is used to prouce a nicly formatted change log from the
git commits (requires git commits to have messages).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The developer is asked whether a new version is required.
Versions must be in the form X.X.XXX where X is a number.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The recipe then updates the change log as well as update several files
throughout APERO and the documentation to update the version and date.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A git tag is also created to mark a new version.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This change is hard to undo. Please use carefully and check
the current version well before making a new version
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This will add all untagged commits to this tag and version. For
multiple commits see section 1.1.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subparagraph{1.1 Adding a few versions at one time}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:adding-a-few-versions-at-one-time}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If there are many commits and a few versions are required one can
add tags using \sphinxtitleref{git tag \{version\} \{commit number\}} at the points
where a new version is required. Using \sphinxtitleref{git log \textendash{}since \{date\} \textgreater{} log.txt}
will produce a log of commit numbers since a date (set this date to the
previous verseion date). Do all but the most recent “version” this way and
then do the last one using apero\_changelog and it will have the desired affect.

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{since} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2020}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{09}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{03} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{log}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{txt}

\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{tag} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.234} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{n}{f95c84d1f54ae70c067aa2d253de31972abe93b}
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{tag} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.235} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{n}{f95c84d1f54ae70c067aa2d253de31972abe93b}
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{tag} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.236} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{n}{fea06752d89151896c5258caecfd3fe12e0c64d}

\PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}changelog}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py}    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} for version 0.1.237}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{2. Schematic}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:schematic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
No schematic set


\subparagraph{3. Usage}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_CLOG:usage}}

\PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}changelog}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{preview}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{k+kc}{False}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
