\paragraph{apero\_database}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DBMGR:apero-database}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DBMGR:dev-tools-default-dbmgr}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DBMGR::doc}}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DBMGR:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: DBMGR

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_database recipe gives some ways to manage the local SQL/MySQL databases and tables.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The options are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
kill all database operations (\textendash{}kill): Rarely the database completely
freezes the \textendash{}kill option should free this up if this is not possible use
the apero\_database\_kill recipe.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
update object database (\textendash{}objdb): Use the online google sheet to update the
local object database

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This requires an internet connection
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
update (\textendash{}update) the calibration, telluric, log and index database using the files on
disk in all the current apero profile data directories (raw/tmp/red/calib/tellu)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
import (\textendash{}importdb) a csv file into either the calibration, telluric, index, log or object database

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Columns must conform with current database definitions
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You must also give the \textendash{}csv argument with the absolute path to the csv file
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The language database can also be imported but this is not recommended
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
use the \textendash{}join option to decide how to add the database (replace removes current database,
append adds the csv contents to the end)
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
export (\textendash{}exportdb) a csv file for the calibration, telluric, index, log or object database.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You must also give the \textendash{}csv argument with the absolute path to the csv file
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The language database can also be imported but this is not recommended
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
manage all apero tables i.e. delete (\textendash{}delete) a database using a GUI to select
which tables (across all APERO profiles)

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Only remove databases you are sure are not being used. This is not
backed up
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{apero\_langdb}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LANG:apero-langdb}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LANG:dev-tools-default-lang}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LANG::doc}}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LANG:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: LANG

\sphinxAtStartPar
apero\_langdb is used to view, update or reload the language database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The view option (\textendash{}find) loads a GUI that provides a search of all
message codes in APERO.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Message codes have the form XX\sphinxhyphen{}XXX\sphinxhyphen{}XXXXX  where each X is a digit.

\sphinxAtStartPar
One can search a code and find all python files which have that message code
and locate some other information about that message code.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The update option (\textendash{}update or \textendash{}upgrade) takes the current database.xsl file
and writes various csv files and update the local language database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Similarly the reload optoin (\textendash{}reload) just updates the local language database
(with the current csv files) this option is useful if updating APEROs version.

\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_LANG:schematic}}

\paragraph{apero\_documentation}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DOC:apero-documentation}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DOC:dev-tools-default-doc}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DOC::doc}}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DOC:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: DOC

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_documentation recipe allows updatings, compiling and uploading of
this documenation (via Sphinx).

\sphinxAtStartPar
One can do this for all instruments (\textendash{}instruments=ALL) or for an individual
instrument (however the compile and upload will re\sphinxhyphen{}compile/re\sphinxhyphen{}upload all
local files).

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the file\_definitions.py has been updated one can use the
\textendash{}filedef argument to update the documentation file definitions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the recipes within recipe\_definitions.py has been updated one can use the
\textendash{}recipedef argument to update the documentation and if the sequences within
recipe\_definitions.py has been updated one can use the \textendash{}recipeseq argument
to update the docuementation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The safest option is to use \textendash{}filedef \textendash{}recipedef \textendash{}recipeseq to update all
automatically created definitions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
One can compile the html and/or latex documents by using \textendash{}compile and change
between compiling html/latex/both with the \textendash{}mode option.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Finally one can \textendash{}upload the changes to the webserver (password will be
required for the rsync)

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
you must make sure \textendash{}compile has been done before this otherwise
you could sync a empty directory and remove all files from the
webserver
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In general one probably runs this command with all arguments.
i.e.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{apero\PYGZus{}documentation}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{filedef} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{recipedef} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{recipeseq} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{compile} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{upload} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{html}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\paragraph{apero\_dependencies}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DEPEND:apero-dependencies}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DEPEND:dev-tools-default-depend}}\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DEPEND::doc}}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_DEPEND:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: DEPEND

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_dependencies recipe takes no arguments.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It scans through all valid python scripts within the apero module and prints
stats on:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the number of lines

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the number of empty lines (no text)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the number of comments

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the number of code lines (not comments)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We aim to have at least as many comments as lines of code, the text will
display in yellow for any script that this is not true for.

\sphinxAtStartPar
At the end the total number of these stats is printed.

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. for 2022\sphinxhyphen{}01\sphinxhyphen{}24

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{l+m+mi}{00}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{48}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mf}{19.152}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}  \PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{DEPEND}\PYG{o}{|}     \PYG{n}{total} \PYG{n}{lines}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{156638}
\PYG{l+m+mi}{00}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{48}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mf}{19.171}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}  \PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{DEPEND}\PYG{o}{|}     \PYG{n}{total} \PYG{n}{empty} \PYG{n}{lines}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{11270}
\PYG{l+m+mi}{00}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{48}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mf}{19.192}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}  \PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{DEPEND}\PYG{o}{|}     \PYG{n}{total} \PYG{n}{lines} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{comments}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{67476}
\PYG{l+m+mi}{00}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{48}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mf}{19.220}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}  \PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{DEPEND}\PYG{o}{|}     \PYG{n}{total} \PYG{n}{lines} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{77892}

\subparagraph{1. Description}
\label{\detokenize{auto/dev_tool_definitions/default/rdefinition_RUN_INI:description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
SHORTNAME: RUN\_INI

\sphinxAtStartPar
The apero\_run\_ini re\sphinxhyphen{}generates all \DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}files} for all instruments using the
current file\_definitions and recipe\_definitions for each instrument.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This does not update the users run.ini files only the ones within the package.
Run apero\_reset to update user run.ini files.

\subsubsection{MySQL example commands}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If using the MySQL database one can make use of direct access to the databases

\sphinxAtStartPar
To accesing mysql (i.e. from bash):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mysql \PYGZhy{}h rali \PYGZhy{}u spirou \PYGZhy{}p
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Get/Show to database/tables

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{SHOW}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{databases}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{USE}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{spirou}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{SHOW}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{tables}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Show columns in a table

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SHOW COLUMNS FROM \PYGZob{}table name\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{\{index table name\}} is the correct index database and \{object table name\}
is the correct object index database from the \sphinxtitleref{SHOW tables;} command above
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\paragraph{Specific example commands:}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/mysql_database_commands:specific-example-commands}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Get count of each object (in raw directory) with counts over 100

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME, COUNT(KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME)
FROM \PYGZob{}index table name\PYGZcb{}
WHERE BLOCK\PYGZus{}KIND=\PYGZdq{}raw\PYGZdq{}
GROUP BY KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME
HAVING COUNT(KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME) \PYGZgt{} 100;
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Get all raw files for a specific night:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT ABSPATH, OBS\PYGZus{}DIR, FILENAME, KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME
FROM \PYGZob{}index table name\PYGZcb{}
WHERE BLOCK\PYGZus{}KIND=\PYGZdq{}raw\PYGZdq{} AND OBS\PYGZus{}DIR=\PYGZdq{}2019\PYGZhy{}06\PYGZhy{}15\PYGZdq{};
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Count the number of e2dsff entries for GL699

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM \PYGZob{}index table name\PYGZcb{}
WHERE block\PYGZus{}kind=\PYGZdq{}red\PYGZdq{} and KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME=\PYGZdq{}GL699\PYGZdq{} and KW\PYGZus{}OUTPUT=\PYGZdq{}EXT\PYGZus{}E2DS\PYGZus{}FF\PYGZdq{};
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Current local object astrometric database

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT OBJNAME, ORIGINAl\PYGZus{}NAME, SP\PYGZus{}TYPE, TEFF
FROM \PYGZob{}object table name\PYGZcb{};
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Combining the INDEX and OBJECT database to find the number of raw files and adding the temperature and spectral
type for each from the object database

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME as name, COUNT(KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME) as counter, c.TEFF, c.SP\PYGZus{}TYPE
FROM \PYGZob{}index table name\PYGZcb{} AS m
INNER JOIN \PYGZob{}object table name\PYGZcb{} c ON c.OBJNAME = m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME
WHERE m.BLOCK\PYGZus{}KIND=\PYGZdq{}raw\PYGZdq{}
GROUP BY m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME;
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Combining the INDEX and OBJECT database to find the number of e2dsff AB files and adding the temperature and spectral
type for each from the object database

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME as name, COUNT(KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME) as counter, c.TEFF, c.SP\PYGZus{}TYPE
FROM \PYGZob{}index table name\PYGZcb{} AS m
INNER JOIN \PYGZob{}object table name\PYGZcb{} AS c ON c.OBJNAME = m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME
WHERE m.BLOCK\PYGZus{}KIND=\PYGZdq{}red\PYGZdq{} AND m.KW\PYGZus{}OUTPUT=\PYGZdq{}EXT\PYGZus{}E2DS\PYGZus{}FF\PYGZdq{} AND m.KW\PYGZus{}FIBER=\PYGZdq{}AB\PYGZdq{}
GROUP BY m.KW\PYGZus{}OBJNAME;
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Getting average timings from the LOG database

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT RECIPE, SHORTNAME, AVG(UNIX\PYGZus{}TIMESTAMP(STR\PYGZus{}TO\PYGZus{}DATE(END\PYGZus{}TIME, \PYGZsq{}\PYGZpc{}Y\PYGZhy{}\PYGZpc{}m\PYGZhy{}\PYGZpc{}d \PYGZpc{}T.\PYGZpc{}f\PYGZsq{})) \PYGZhy{} UNIX\PYGZus{}TIMESTAMP(STR\PYGZus{}TO\PYGZus{}DATE(START\PYGZus{}TIME, \PYGZsq{}\PYGZpc{}Y\PYGZhy{}\PYGZpc{}m\PYGZhy{}\PYGZpc{}d \PYGZpc{}T.\PYGZpc{}f\PYGZsq{}))) as dt
FROM \PYGZob{}log table name\PYGZcb{}
WHERE ENDED=1
GROUP BY SHORTNAME;
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Getting the recipe count, average start/end RAM/CPU usage

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT RECIPE, SHORTNAME, COUNT(SHORTNAME), AVG(RAM\PYGZus{}USAGE\PYGZus{}START), AVG(RAM\PYGZus{}USAGE\PYGZus{}END), AVG(CPU\PYGZus{}USAGE\PYGZus{}START), AVG(CPU\PYGZus{}USAGE\PYGZus{}END)
FROM \PYGZob{}log table name\PYGZcb{}
WHERE ENDED=1
GROUP BY SHORTNAME;
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Counting recipes that did not finish

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{SELECT}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{RECIPE}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{SHORTNAME}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{COUNT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{SHORTNAME}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{FROM}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{LOG\PYGZus{}setup\PYGZus{}spirou\PYGZus{}stable\PYGZus{}07\PYGZus{}DB}
\PYG{k}{WHERE}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{ENDED}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
\PYG{k}{GROUP}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{BY}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n}{SHORTNAME}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Python installation}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-installation}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:id1}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can install the modules required to run APERO in three ways (eventually
there will be a \sphinxtitleref{setup.py} but not yet!

\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently supported options are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-install-miniconda}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{install miniconda}}}} (recommended)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-install-anaconda}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{install anaconda}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-install-pip}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{install via pip only (i.e. in a venv)}}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once python and the required modules are correctly installed you can
install APERO \sphinxhyphen{} see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We do not recommend ever using the base environment or the
system python for installing modules or running the APERO codes.

\subsection{Installing miniconda (with supplied environment)}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:installing-miniconda-with-supplied-environment}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/pythoninstallation:python-install-miniconda}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is recommended for maximum compatibility

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you already use miniconda (with python 3) skip to step 3

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Make sure the miniconda you download/have is miniconda3
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Download miniconda3, i.e. in bash and wget (or go to the
anaconda website \sphinxurl{https:/repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/})

\sphinxAtStartPar
i.e. the current latest version of Miniconda3 for Linux is this:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
wget https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3\PYGZhy{}latest\PYGZhy{}Linux\PYGZhy{}x86\PYGZus{}64.sh
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install miniconda, i.e. with bash
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bash Miniconda3\PYGZhy{}latest\PYGZhy{}Linux\PYGZhy{}x86\PYGZus{}64.sh
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create a conda environment
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
conda env create \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}name \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}YOUR ENV NAME\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{n+nv}{python}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m}{3}.9
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
where \sphinxtitleref{\{YOUR ENV NAME\}} should be a suitable name for the apero conda environemnt
(e.g. \sphinxtitleref{setup\_07XXX\_mini1} or \sphinxtitleref{full\_07111})
\end{quote}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You should now have an environment called \sphinxtitleref{\{YOUR ENV NAME\}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Before running or installing APERO you must be in this conda environment, i.e. type:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
conda activate \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}YOUR ENV NAME\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can now install APERO (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/general/installation:installation}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{here}}}})

\section{Glossary}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:glossary}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:id1}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary::doc}}

\subsection{Detailed Constants}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:detailed-constants}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:glossary-constants}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These are usually defined in the instruments \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_config.py}} and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_constants.py}} scripts and are overwritten in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{user\_config.ini}} and
:file\textasciigrave{}user\_constant.ini\textasciigrave{} files.
\begin{description}
\item[{DRS\_ROOT\index{DRS\_ROOT@\spxentry{DRS\_ROOT}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_ROOT}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the path where apero\sphinxhyphen{}drs was installed (via github)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a suggested directory is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/home/user/bin/apero\sphinxhyphen{}drs}}

\end{itemize}

\item[{DRS\_UCONFIG\index{DRS\_UCONFIG@\spxentry{DRS\_UCONFIG}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_UCONFIG}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The directory containing the users configurations files

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
default is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/home/user/apero/\sphinxstyleemphasis{PROFILE}}}

\end{itemize}

\item[{DrsInputFile\index{DrsInputFile@\spxentry{DrsInputFile}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DrsInputFile}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a class controlling how files are defined \sphinxhyphen{} it comes in three
flavors \sphinxhyphen{} a generic file type (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.core.drs\_file.DrsInputFile()}}),
a fits file type (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.core.drs\_file.DrsFitsFile()}}) and a
temporary numpy file type (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.core.drs\_file.DrsNPYFile()}})

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\subsection{Detailed Keywords}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:detailed-keywords}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These are usually defined in the instruments \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_keywords.py}} script.
These keywords control what keys are read from fits headers and also what
keys and comments are saved to fits headers.
\begin{description}
\item[{KW\_GAIA\_ID\index{KW\_GAIA\_ID@\spxentry{KW\_GAIA\_ID}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_GAIA_ID}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the gaia id key from the header

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The header value should contain a valid gaia id

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is used to cross\sphinxhyphen{}match with the object database and with
gaia online database to get position and velocity data precise enough
for a good BERV correction

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If key is missing or invalid the BERV calculation defers to the header
values for position and velocity (may be less precise).

\end{itemize}

\item[{KW\_OBJECTNAME\index{KW\_OBJECTNAME@\spxentry{KW\_OBJECTNAME}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_OBJECTNAME}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the object name used from the header

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the unmodified value from the fits file creation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
It is cleaned and then added to a new header key ({\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-4}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_OBJNAME}}}})

\end{itemize}

\item[{KW\_OBJNAME\index{KW\_OBJNAME@\spxentry{KW\_OBJNAME}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_OBJNAME}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the cleaned object name \sphinxhyphen{} suitable for use throughout APERO.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently it is cleaned using and instruments {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PseudoConst}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{PseudoConst}}}} cleaning function
e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.pseudo\_const.clean\_obj\_name()}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\subsection{General}
\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:general}}\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:glossary-main}}\begin{description}
\item[{block\_kind\index{block\_kind@\spxentry{block\_kind}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-block_kind}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
this is the type of file we have related to the various data directories

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
valid block kinds are: “raw”, “tmp”, “red”, “calib”, “tellu”

\end{itemize}

\item[{ds9\index{ds9@\spxentry{ds9}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-ds9}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An astronomical imaging and data visualization application

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
see \sphinxhref{http://ds9.si.edu/site/Home.html}{ds9.si.edu}

\end{itemize}

\item[{engineering\sphinxhyphen{}directories\index{engineering\sphinxhyphen{}directories@\spxentry{engineering\sphinxhyphen{}directories}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-engineering-directories}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This are directories without science observations in

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
In general we do not recommend to reduce these nights as they may
reduce the quality of reduced data

\end{itemize}

\item[{file\sphinxhyphen{}definitions\index{file\sphinxhyphen{}definitions@\spxentry{file\sphinxhyphen{}definitions}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-file-definitions}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is an instrument specific python script that defines all the
file types for use with this instrument (raw, preprocessed, output).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each file definition is a {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DrsInputFile}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DrsInputFile}}}} instance

\end{itemize}

\item[{INSTRUMENT\index{INSTRUMENT@\spxentry{INSTRUMENT}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-INSTRUMENT}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the instrument used at a specific telescope. Some settings are instrument specific.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently supported instruments are::
SPIROU, NIRPS\_HA, NIRPS\_HE

\end{itemize}

\item[{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory\index{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory@\spxentry{observation\sphinxhyphen{}directory}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-observation-directory}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the sub\sphinxhyphen{}directories within the raw directory (define by {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-DRS_DATA_RAW}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{DRS\_DATA\_RAW}}}}) that individual
observations are separated into, this is recommended to be on a night\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}night basis but can be split in
other ways (for example by object name).

\end{itemize}

\item[{PID\index{PID@\spxentry{PID}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PID}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The unique process id for this specific {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-recipe-run}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Stored in the header using {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-KW_PID}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{KW\_PID}}}}

\end{itemize}

\item[{pdflatex\index{pdflatex@\spxentry{pdflatex}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-pdflatex}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The pdf latex compiler

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
see \sphinxhref{https://www.latex-project.org/get/}{www.latex\sphinxhyphen{}project.org}

\end{itemize}

\item[{pre\sphinxhyphen{}processing\sphinxhyphen{}coordinate\sphinxhyphen{}system\index{pre\sphinxhyphen{}processing\sphinxhyphen{}coordinate\sphinxhyphen{}system@\spxentry{pre\sphinxhyphen{}processing\sphinxhyphen{}coordinate\sphinxhyphen{}system}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-pre-processing-coordinate-system}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the standard coordinate system for pre\sphinxhyphen{}processed images

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
It consists of the bluest wavelength at the top right and the reddest
order in the bottom left

\end{itemize}

\item[{PROFILE\index{PROFILE@\spxentry{PROFILE}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PROFILE}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a short descriptive name given to a specific set of installation configurations

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each profile contains setup files: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxstyleemphasis{PROFILE}.bash.setup file}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxstyleemphasis{PROFILE}.sh.setup file}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each profile contains an instrument directory for each instrument. These contain user\_config.ini and user\_constant.ini files for said instrument.

\end{itemize}

\item[{PseudoConst\index{PseudoConst@\spxentry{PseudoConst}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-PseudoConst}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is an instrument specific class that has functions that cannot be
simply defined by an integer, float or string

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Sometimes pseudo constant methods require input and are hence dynamic

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
They are located in the instrument directory
e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.spirou.psuedo\_const()}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is also a default psuedo constant class which all instruments
inherit from \sphinxhyphen{} if no instrument is defined, or a method is not defined
for a specific instrument it will default to this method \sphinxhyphen{} this is stored
in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apero.core.instruments.default.psuedo\_const()}}

\end{itemize}

\item[{recipe\index{recipe@\spxentry{recipe}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-recipe}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a python script for use directly by the user

\end{itemize}

\item[{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run\index{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run@\spxentry{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-recipe-run}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An individual, single, run of a given recipe, all required arguments for a single
recipe\sphinxhyphen{}run should be given before running

\end{itemize}

\item[{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequence, recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequences\index{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequence, recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequences@\spxentry{recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequence, recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequences}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-recipe-sequence-recipe-sequences}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A recipe sequence is a set of recipes to be run in a certain order, with
certain parameters, the sequences are set up such that the apero\_processing recipe
can take all files in the raw directory (or a sub\sphinxhyphen{}set of these) and figure out
all recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs in a recipe\sphinxhyphen{}sequence for all the valid raw files. A sequence
can be only a few different recipes or all recipes required for the full reduction
of the raw data from start to finish.

\end{itemize}

\item[{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file\index{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file@\spxentry{run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-run-ini-file}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the file used in apero\_processing recipe to switch on and off recipes in sequences,
to skip recipes, and indicate other processing features (such as the number of cores)
these are also used in the apero\_precheck to give some indication on what will happen
when the apero\_processing recipe is run. If no sequences are given one can use
the run.ini files as a batch processor where individual recipe\sphinxhyphen{}runs can be given

\end{itemize}

\item[{shortname\index{shortname@\spxentry{shortname}|spxpagem}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{main/misc/glossary:term-shortname}}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a shortened name for a specific recipe, these are used in log files, when
turning off and skipping recipes in a :term:run\sphinxhyphen{}ini\sphinxhyphen{}file and elsewhere to
reference a specific recipe, please check the recipe definitions for the link
between short name and recipe names (Note some sequences alter shortnames when
they need to be unique from the recipes themselves).

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
